qas.question: How did bands associated with the original post-punk movement cause it to end?
What type of music did many of the post-punk bands start indulging in?
What venue drove a lot of the awareness of the music from the now pop post-punk bands?
Where was a lot of the post-punk pop bands played in addition to MTV?
What band combined religious imagery with political commentary into their music?
What was the death knell of the post-punk movement?
What else would the post-punk bands record under?
What was one of the most popular concepts of the pop movement?
What was a driving force behind the revival of the second British Invasion of New Music to America?

answers.text: MTV and modern rock radio stations

qas.question: Who was the most successful band to arrise from post-punk?
What did bands associated with post-punk never turn away from?
Where was post-punk not driven by MTV or modern rock radio stations?
Who decided not to shift their sound?
Which bands were least successful during post-punk?

context: The original post-punk movement ended as the bands associated with the movement <a0_0>turned away from <b10_0>its aesthetics<b10_0/><a0_0/>, often in favor of more <a5_0>commercial sounds<a5_0/>. Many of these groups would continue recording as part of the new <a1_0><a6_0>pop<a6_0/><a1_0/> movement, with <a7_0>entryism<a7_0/> becoming a popular concept. In the <b11_0>United States<b11_0/>, driven by <a2_0><a8_0>MTV<a2_0/> and modern rock radio stations<a8_0/>, a number of post-punk acts had an influence on or became part of the Second British Invasion of "New Music" there. Some shifted to a more commercial new wave sound (such as <b12_0>Gang of Four<b12_0/>), while others were fixtures on <a3_0>American college radio<a3_0/> and became early examples of alternative rock. Perhaps the most successful band to emerge from post-punk was <a4_0><a9_0><b13_0>U2<b13_0/><a9_0/><a4_0/>, who combined elements of religious imagery together with political commentary into their often anthemic music.
